metadata.author: IBM Technology

key_facts: A context window is the equivalent of a language model's working memory.
The context window determines how long a conversation an LLM can maintain without forgetting earlier details.
Context windows are measured in tokens, not IBUs as humorously suggested.
Tokens are the smallest unit of language used by AI models, representing characters, parts of words, whole words, or short phrases.
A tokenizer converts text into tokens, and different tokenizers may produce different results for the same text.
A typical English word is represented by about 1.5 tokens on average.
Transformer models use self-attention to calculate relationships between tokens in a sequence.
Self-attention computes weights showing how relevant each token is to others in the input.
The IBM Granite 3 model has a context window of 128,000 tokens.
Early LLMs had context windows around 2,000 tokens.
System prompts are included in the context window and condition model behavior.
User inputs, model responses, attached documents, source code, and RAG data can all occupy space in the context window.
Longer context windows increase the risk of hallucinations due to missing earlier information.
Models may make educated guesses when earlier context is outside the window.
Performance degrades when relevant information is located in the middle of long contexts.
key_opinions: Using IBUs to measure context windows was a humorous fabrication.
A 128K token window might seem like overkill at first glance.
Larger context windows present significant computational challenges.
Long context lengths can cause models to become lazy and take cognitive shortcuts.
Balancing context size with performance and safety is essential.
The idea that more context always equals better performance is misleading.
The current trend toward larger context windows may be driven more by capability than necessity.
Safety mechanisms are less effective with longer context windows.
Jailbreaking becomes harder to detect in long-context inputs.
There is no universally optimal context window sizeâ€”trade-offs must be considered.
key_datapoints: Early LLMs had context windows of around 2,000 tokens.
IBM Granite 3 has a context window of 128,000 tokens.
A regular English word is typically represented by approximately 1.5 tokens.
A 100-word passage may result in roughly 150 tokens.
Compute requirements scale quadratically with sequence length.
Doubling the number of input tokens increases processing power needs by four times.
A 2023 study found model performance peaks when relevant info is near the start or end of context.
Middle-context information leads to performance degradation in long sequences.
System prompts are included in the context window but often hidden from users.
RAG-supplied data can be stored within the context window during inference.
